Emergency Action Plan (19 CCR §2765.1)
Ripon Energy's fully implemented Safety Program Library includes an Emergency Action Plan Program, which is reviewed annually.
For responses beyond plant personnel capabilities, Ripon Energy relies on the Ripon Fire District, with which it has a continuous working relationship.

Training (19 CCR §2760.4)
Ripon Energy provides documented initial and refresher training for employees conducting activities involved in the maintenance and operation of the Covered Process - and consults with employees about the frequency of training.

Record Keeping (19 CCR §2775.1)
Ripon Energy maintains RMP implementation records for five years.

Process Safety Management (PSM) (8 CCR §5189.1) & Process Safety Information (PSI) (19 CCR §2760.1)
Ripon Energy's Covered Process is subject to the Cal OSHA PSM requirements per the regulatory references below.
Ripon Energy's PSM includes all of the Program 3 elements presented in the Program document, including various safety programs, operating procedures, maintenance procedures, and PSI.
Ripon Energy's PSI includes Operating Procedures, P&IDs, MOC and PSSR practices, MI practices, audits, audits/inspections and associated findings, forms, Regulated Substance Information, Technology Information (19 CCR §2760.1(c)), Block Flow Diagram or Simplified Process Flow Diagram (8 CCR §5189(d)(2)(a)), Process Chemistry (8 CCR §5189(d)(2)(b)), Maximum Intended Inventory (8 CCR §5189(d)(2)(c)), Safe Upper and Lower Limits (8 CCR §5189(d)(2)(d)), Consequences of Deviations (8 CCR §5189(d)(2)(e)), Materials of Construction (8 CCR §5189(d)(3)(a)(1)), Electrical Classification (8 CCR §5189(d)(3)(a)(3)), Pressure Safety Relief System Design and Design Basis (8 CCR §5189(d)(3)(a)(4)).

EXECUTIVE SUMMARY (19 CCR §2745.3)


Certification (19 CCR §2745.2. §2745.9)

Ripon Energy's CalARP / RMP Program is certified by informed and qualified individuals to be true in its content and implemented to the best of the facility's capabilities.


Risk Management Plan Overview

AltaGas Ripon Energy Inc. (Ripon Energy) owns and operates an electricity generation facility (facility) at 944 South Stockton Ave., Ripon, California in San Joaquin County, California, in an area of primarily light industrial use.

The facility has one chemical in one process (Covered Process) as defined in the regulations that is regulated under the California Accidental Release Prevention Program (CalARP) (Title 19, California Code of Regulations (CCR), Chapter 4.5).  

Ripon Energy's Covered Process is the Ammonia System, which uses Refrigeration Grade (99+ %) anhydrous ammonia (CAS No. 7664 41 7) (1) as the refrigerant in an Ammonia Refrigeration System, also known as a Gas Turbine Inlet Air Chiller (Chiller) System and (2) as a reactant for NOx emissions reduction in a Selective Catalytic Reduction (SCR) System.


General Requirements

Ripon Energy's CalARP / RMP is RMP Program Level 3 (19 CCR §2735.4).

Ripon Energy maintains a Management System (19 CCR §2735.6) that assigns responsibilities and resources for implementing EPA and CalARP/RMP provisions.  
EPA RMP Registration Information (19 CCR §2740.1) is included in the Program.

Ripon Energy submits to EPA (19 CCR §2745.1) (19 CCR §2735.5) via RMP E SUBMIT and to the San Joaquin County Environmental Health Department (Administering Agency, AA) as required.

Ripon Energy updates (19 CCR §2745.10) and corrects (19 CCR §2745.10.5) the RMP per regulation.  Ripon Energy also follows the regulation for Covered Process Modifications (19 CCR §2745.11).


Hazard Assessment

Ripon Energy performs Hazard Assessment (19 CCR §2750.1) which includes Two Toxic Worst-Case Release Scenario analyses (19 CCR §2750.3

) and six Toxic Alternative Release Scenarios (19 CCR §2750.4).  

The scenarios include Offsite Consequence Analysis (OCA) (19 CCR §2750.2), per RMP EPA OCA Guidance, that provide definition of Offsite Impacts to the Population (19 CCR §2750.5) and Offsite Impacts to the Environment (19 CCR §2750.6), including distances to Toxic Endpoints.

Ripon Energy reviews and updates the OCA at least once every five years or more frequently as defined the regulation (19 CCR §2750.7).  


Five-Year Accident History

Ripon Energy presents a Five-Year Accident History (19 CCR §2750.9) in the Program Document.  Ripon Energy has had zero accidental releases in the five year period preceding the date of this document.

Ripon Energy's documentation of Accident History would include initiating events, onsite impacts, offsite impacts, offsite response, and corrective measures.


Level 3 Prevention Program

Ripon Energy is has implemented a Prevention Program consistent with Level 3 requirements.  The Prevention Program includes:

Process Hazard Analysis (PHA) (19 CCR §2760.2)
Ripon Energy conducts Process Hazard Analysis (PHA) at least every five years to identify, evaluate, and control the risk associated with process hazards or chemical release scenarios involving the Covered Process.  The most recent PHA utilized a what-if analysis and was completed in November 2017.  Action Items are tracked to completion in Program documents.

Operating Procedures (19 CCR §2760.3)
Ripon Energy maintains written procedures to operate systems in the Covered Process that include operating limits, safety and health considerations, and safety systems functionality.  Applicable Operating Procedures are reviewed, updated, and certified annually or when changes are made to the Ammonia System.  Revisions are documented in the revision history of the procedure.

Safe Work Practices (19 CCR §2760.3)
Ripon Energy maintains written Safety Programs to ensure Safe Work that include:
ssociated subordinate procedures, forms, etc.  The Library is scheduled for a complete review cycle, commencing in 2019 and continuing for several years.

Training Program, Safety Observation Program, Incident Management Program, Personnel Onsite Program, First Aid /CPR / AED Program, Bloodborne Pathogens Program, PPE Program, Respiratory Protection Program, Safe Work Program (Work Permits, Job Hazard Analysis, and Job Briefings), LOTO Program, Hot Work Program, Haz Mat / Haz Com / WHMIS Program, and Ha Mat Hazardous Substances Management Program.

Mechanical Integrity (MI) (19 CCR §2760.5)
Ripon Energy maintains MI practices to ensure continued integrity of the Covered Process equipment by maintaining, inspecting, and testing equipment consistent with manufacturers' recommendations and good engineering practices.  The MI practices include inventory of process equipment; process and instrumentation diagrams; maintenance, inspection, and testing schedules; and maintenance documentation. 

Management of Change (MOC) (19 CCR §2760.6) and Pre-Startup Safety Review (PSSR) (19 CCR §2760.7)
Ripon Energy uses an integrated MOC / PSSR procedure to safely and efficiently manage changes to the Covered Process.

Compliance Audits (19 CCR §2760.8)
Ripon Energy conducts audits for compliance with EPA RMP, CalARP, and California Process Safety Management Standard requirements at least once every three years, most recently in November 2017.

Incident Investigation (19 CCR §2760.9)
Ripon Energy investigates all incidents and near-miss events.

Employee Participation (19 CCR §2760.10)
Ripon Energy solicits and (in some cases) requires the participation of employees (and where applicable, their representatives) in the advancement of the RMP program.  At least one employee has direct involvement in the PHA process.  
Ripon Energy employees (and where applicable, their representatives) have access to all CalARP/RMP documentation.

Hot Work Permits (19 CCR §2760.11)
Ripon Energy's fully implemented Safety Program Library includes a Hot Work Permit Program.
